critique: This document is an executive order approving a code of fair competition for the Business Furniture, Storage Equipment, and Filing Supply Industry, pursuant to the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933. The document itself doesn't express a clear ideological stance but enacts policy based on existing legislation. The NIRA was a New Deal program, so it reflects a liberal approach to economic regulation. There's no direct impact on immigration, executive power (beyond implementing existing law), federalism, national security, or social inclusion. However, the approval of a code of fair competition implies government intervention in the economy.
